But I bought it because Uncharted 3 came with my system. So even though 1 sucked, REALLY, REALLY SUCKED...I reluctantly bought 2. I'm glad I was wearing socks, because they were blown clean off. What a phenomenally great game! The writing was pure entertainment, the game pay was fun and addictive, the melee combat is usable now, the guns fights are well paced and don't drag on for too long. The graphics are just stellar, the textures on wet cave walls and the stairs in ancient ruins is just jaw dropping. I won't say anymore...But, if, like me, you played and hated 1 and gave up on the series, please do yourself a favour and revisit it. This game is amazing, one of the best I have ever played.

The original Uncharted Drake's fortune was without a doubt one of the best games released for the PS3. It had great cut-scenes, beautiful graphics, simple puzzles and gameplay with a never-ending sense of fun. This has very much carried over with it's sequel with even more polished features, though the design is starting to feel a bit redundant.Uncharted 2 has even MORE impressive graphics than the first game. I mean seriously this game will blow you away with it's presentation. The story is MUCH more involved, the locations are much more varied (and again: beautiful!) and despite a some dull first few missions you're pretty much hooked until the end. The characters are just as charming in this sequel with a few new names to cast and everyone is voice-acted (and motion captured) to perfection.Unfortunately what the game improved with production, it lacks in the gameplay. The controls are even more polished to make combat, climbing and stealth much smoother but you're pretty much doing the same things you did in the first Uncharted. There's some great level designs, especially in urban environments but when you get to the jungle and outdoor levels (particularly the last level) everything feels a bit too familiar and redundant. Everythign you do in this game are things you did in the first Uncharted game....just more polished. I hate to call that a complaint but despite some eye-catching moments I couldn't help but feel a bit underwhelmed. Even the three puzzles were pretty mindless (though the one with the giant dagger was well designed).Despite my complaining I still like this game a lot. It's fun (to be fair MORE fun than the first Uncharted), funny and has great graphics and cut scenes. I know I'm in the minority here I just wish some more time would've been put into the gameplay innovation.

summary: One of THE Best Games of This Console Generation
reviewText: I played the first Uncharted and was so impressed by it that I naturally had to play the second to see what happens next to our hero Nathan Drake. After playing the second one I can say without hesitation that this one surpasses the first in every way. I didn't think that they could outdo the first but they did. The action is non-stop and the story line is very good. I even had a few chuckles from the dialogues that took place. The only thing that I would say that is negative is that the shooting mechanics are not the best. But then I am used to the shooting and cover mechanics of the Call of Duty series. One must realize that this is not primarily an first person shooter. This is mainly a third person action game. The most annoying thing about this game is the grenade throwing mechanics which are quite frustrating. But then again, I am used to the Call of Duty grenade throwing mechanics which allow you to throw grenades in a more natural fashion. These negative attributes, though, do not in any way remove this game from a five star rating as I realize that this game is a third person action game first. Also, if you have played any of the Prince of Persia games, you will feel right at home. The jumping, climbing and pole swinging are very similar. Some of the set pieces really looked like Prince of Persia's. The gears especially reminded me of the ones in Prince of Persia. Be aware, though, that it can get quite challenging if you are a casual gamer. But there is an easy mode for those of us who have a job and family to take care of. This game is for those who enjoy the story as much as the game mechanics. I really felt immersed in the world of Uncharted and often could not stop playing. I was trying to limit myself to one chapter at a time to help make the experience last. I often found myself playing two chapters in one sitting just because I could not stop. If you own a Playstation 3, this is the reason, besides the free online play on Playstation's Network, to own this system. I have the Playstation 3 and Xbox 360 and the Xbox 360 is just collecting dust. Why? Because the available games on the Playstation 3 and the fact that you can play most online games for free on Playstation Network. Xbox 360 requires you to pay a monthly or yearly toll and that is just not right.

If anyone complains this game is too short, it's the AVERAGE length nowadays. Reach, modern warfare 2, left for dead, ect are all only like 4-5 hours long, so to hold this to an expected longer standard is just crazy. At least the game matched the campaign length, and more importantly, the quality of some titles that had 3x the staff size

Being new to the Splinter cell series, I must admit, Im blown away! Everything about this game is absolutely incredible. The story, graphics, voice acting and level design are all top notch! Im only 3 levels in but im having a blast with this game! So if u are new to the series like me and like sneeking around? Then this is a definate must buy. A perfect 10 out of 10!  Thanx for reading.

description: You ain't got nothing against a superhero hedgehog. Step into the shoes of one of the most popular video game characters of all time inSonic the Hedgehog. Blaze through each level, using spin attacks and bursts of speed to get where you're going. Use loops to defy gravity, and then dash to safety in Sonic's power sneakers. You'll traverse hot lava, waterfalls, beautiful mountaintops, and zoom through a magical city along your journey to rescue your friends from the clutches of evil. Full of rotating mazes, unprecedented obstacles, and deadly enemies,Sonic the Hedgehogis a long-standing classic for the Genesis.
reviewText: Sonic The Hedgehog 1 for the Sega Genesis system is one of the greatest video games ever created. For those that don't know, It is getting a 15th anniversary Gameboy Advance Re-release in November, 2006. It will feature 2 new features. The first feature, will be a save feature and the second, Sonic will be able to do the spin-dash thing he was able to in Sonic 2. I'm so excited. I hope that they re-release Sonic 2 (with Knuckles), 3 (with knuckles), and Sonic And Knuckles on GBA on their 15th anniversary.

description: Assassin?s Creedis the next-gen game developed by Ubisoft Montreal that will redefine the action genre. While other games claim to be next-gen with impressive graphics and physics,Assassin?s Creedmerges technology, game design, theme, and emotions into a world where you instigate chaos and become a vulnerable, yet powerful, agent of change.The setting is 1191 AD. The Third Crusade is tearing the Holy Land apart. You, Altair, intend to stop the hostilities by suppressing both sides of the conflict.You are an Assassin, a warrior shrouded in secrecy and feared for your ruthlessness. Your actions can throw your immediate environment into chaos, and your existence will shape events during this pivotal moment in history.Key FeaturesBe an Assassin: Master the skills, tactics, and weapons of history?s deadliest and most secretive clan of warriors. Plan your attacks, strike without mercy, and fight your way to escape.Realistic and responsive environments: Crowds react to your moves and will either help or hinder you on your quests.Action with a new dimension - total freedom: Eliminate your targets wherever, whenever, and however. Stalk your prey through richly detailed, historically accurate, open-ended environments. Scale buildings, mount horses, blend in with crowds. Do whatever it takes to achieve your objectives.Relive the epic times of the Crusades:Assassin?s Creedimmerses you in the realistic and historical Holy Land of the 12th century, featuring life-like graphics, ambience, and the subtle, yet detailed nuances of a living world.Intense action rooted in reality: Experience heavy action blended with fluid and precise animations. Use a wide range of medieval weapons, and face your enemies in realistic swordfight duels.Next-gen gameplay: The proprietary engine developed from the ground up for the next-gen console allows organic game design featuring open gameplay, intuitive control scheme, realistic interaction with environment, and a fluid, yet sharp, combat mechanic.
summary: GREAT START FOR A GREAT FRANCHISE !!!!
reviewText: I LOVED THE GAME SINCE I STARTED TO PLAY, FROM THE BEGINNING TO THE FINAL CREDITS I HAVE A CERTAINLY THAT THIS GAME BECOME A GREAT FRANCHISE.

description: Set in a futuristic utopia, an elite peacekeeping force thwarts the rumblings of civil war. But deception within the ranks has caused two members of the most feared unit to strike out on their own. Now stranded on an abandoned paradise, Grayson Hunt and Ishi Sato find themselves surrounded by hordes of mutants and flesh eating gangs. They survive on two objectives: get off the planet alive and extract revenge on the man who sent them there. As Grayson Hunt, players wield an arsenal of over-the-top combat moves and outrageously large guns that feed into Bulletstorm’s distinct ‘skillshot’ system producing unprecedented levels of frantic gameplay and yell-inducing satisfaction.
reviewText: As a huge fan of Epic Games and the Gears franchise, I was very excited about this game. But after playing it I am very dissappointed overall.The Pros...Anarchy Mode (Although it was poorly implemented, see below)Pretty good visualsNice weaponsSolid enough campaignYou can actually customize your characters, which was something that was absent in Gears and Gears 2. A nice addition.ConsNo co-op campaign. I realize this may not work with the whole "kill with skill" gimmick, but its not a good excuse to not have it, in my opinion.Poorly implemented Anarchy Mode. Although the concept is great, and I still play horde mode a couple of times a week, they really dropped the ball here. They rush you between rounds when you have to purchase your weapons, upgrades and ammo. They give you 30 seconds and then that's it, you have to wait until the next round. Why put a time limit on this?Many times the combinations don't execute properly or you aren't awarded the points even when you do exactly what you were supposed to.Only a handful of maps doesn't help any at all. I know that its probably difficult to make maps for a game like this because of all the interactive elements on each level, but they should have had a few more.I enjoyed the campaign and the anarchy mode will provide you with a few hours of enjoyment, but you'll soon tire of the kill with skill gimmick. I'll probably trade the game in next week; its not worth holding onto even for the Gears 3 Beta.

For me, pre "Black"-album Metallica is the single best band in the last 30 years. While I liked them less and less following "...And Justice for All", I absolutely love the band. So, buying this game was a no-brainer for me.But you know what? I would recommend it to anyone who just wants to have a great GH workout. This game is immensely fun on expert level, and therefore I am confident that, depending on your style and level of play, the appropriate difficult would be fun for you. While I was a little sad to see some of the songs put on here ("No Leaf Clover", e.g.), it was great to get a large dose of "Master of Puppets" (only two tracks are missing!), together with solid offerings from all of "Kill 'Em All", "Ride the Lightning" (although the title track is missing - for shame!) and "...And Justice for All" (I would have liked "Blackened" and the title track). In addition, they take my single favorite Metallica cover (the 11:30 "Mercyful Fate")...and a lot of other slop. But I was more happy with the selection here than that found on the odious "GH: Aerosmith".In addition, there is a large collection of guest acts, many of whom will seem quite esoteric to the non-Metallica fan (Diamondhead, Samhain and Mercyful Fate aren't bands that typically roll off the tongue today). I was incredibly pleased with the offering, but some might be left scratching their heads. One caveat: if you are one that is offended by occult lyrics, you might want to stay away. There is a lot of this to be found here.So, in short, I love the game. Not only is it fun, but it is challenging as well. If I had a complaint, it is that the trophies here are more for advertising online play and other instruments (you have to play EVERY instrument career to get some trophies, and you even have to download a song). None of them are hugely difficult (e.g. there is nothing like the "Enlightened Guitarist" achievement X-Box owners might remember from "GH 3: Legends of Rock", but they can be annoying to get. Still, this is a worthy buy.

summary: Windows 7 has some issues w. game out of the box, but works otherwise
reviewText: If you are running Windows 7, first thing you will want to do is download the Games for Windows Live client. The version that shipped with the physical copy of the game is old and doesn't install properly or work properly under Windows 7. Or at least, that's my experience.I installed the game (which took "forever") and found I couldn't change any options and couldn't exit some of the menu items without quitting the game completely. It turns out that the game needs an update for itself, BUT, it also needs the latest Windows 7 version of the Games for Windows Live client. Once I installed the patch and the client, the game worked without issue.The game itself is a port of the 2006 XBox 360 release. The biggest difference is that there is an extra chapter not available anywhere else. This is why I bought the game - I wanted to play this chapter. While the chapter isn't bad, it isn't really necessary and isn't ever really referenced anywhere else in the games, novels or comics. So while it is canon, it's much like the first TPB of the comic - OK, not great, mostly forgettable and can't hurt canon because it doesn't offer much.Graphically, this version, assuming you have a decent video card, is superior to the 360 version given you can get much higher resolutions and texture quality.I love the ability to create maps, but there aren't a ton of people playing anymore, so this is more an exercise in having fun building than building something a bunch of other people will play.For the used game price of $20, it was worth it for the extra chapter. For the price people are asking for a new boxed copy, or even the original MSRP, it's not worth it at all if you have the game on the 360.

*slight edit*I realized I was wrong about something before, the ending videos are in 3d, it's just not as intense as I'd expected cause of Tekken Hybrid.  In some movies it really stands out, but in most it's a very basic and very slight overall haze that makes the glasses cause the colors to pop more.Also the first content update dropped today - 3 new characters, 4 new stages, some exploits have been fixed, and a new online mode.  That's awesome :D**Title aside, Tekken Tag 2 has great graphics (Probably 3rd best 3d support on the PS3), controls, decent online interface, lots of items to customize your character with, and hard core fans were though of when this game was made.Tekken Tag 2 is a great game and it's geared toward its fans.  If you don't have time to set aside and practice and get great at this game, as you probably did with the previous games, then it's not for you.I've bought every Tekken game since... 3 I think.  I play them a lot and it's pretty simple - I beat arcade with everyone to see the neat little ending videos, I play with friends when they come by (back then more often than now) and that's it.Oh and I played Bowling for Tekken Tag 1 like crazy.As someone who doesn't have time to practice a lot and who just wants to get off work, play the game for an hour, and maybe see a neat video or two... It's the worse game ever made. I've never had such an annoying time with an end boss as the pair that this game ends with.  Like... Go through Arcade lasts me 1 hour annoying. I'm not someone who claims to be a pro gamer or anything, but I've played tons of fighting games in the past and eventually 'figured it out', this one... not so much. Just cheap tactics and it doesn't get any easy for me, at least.To rub it in worse the game doesn't have great loading times.. and you don't have option to 'try again' with the same characters you just played as, so you have to go through the full loading rotation of bringing up the character select screen and re-selecting your characters (which sometimes gives you a good 5 second lag inbetween the first and second because of random loading).But, if you're some all star Tekken hotshot who has memorized a character or two, that won't even bother you. So really consider your ability before you buy this game planning to earn a Platinum or go through the Arcade a bunch. You'll hope Jun is never in another Tekken game by the 4-5 run through.And so I won't take points off for that, the 1 star was lost because of -Loading Times - especially restarting a fight in arcade - you're looking at about 45 seconds before you're able to play again.Loading times also really suck in the shop where you customize your characters.  Yeah I got a bathing suit for every character.. but it would literally take me 2 hours to 'add' a costume for each character that has the bathing suit equipped.They took out Handicap or any way to control how much HP you have. Since Tekken is such a high-damage game (this one particularly) my buddies and I used to use this to make the rounds last longer than 2 hits by Paul... This game has absolutely no version of the option anywhere.And my Pros again -Controls - Very fluid, and they did a great job making the Tag system and moves related to it easy to use.Graphics - Beautiful and great 3d if you have a TV that supports it.Character selection - there is space for more and I hope I still have the game once they come out :POnline - I've yet to feel any lag and the practice mode while waiting is... cute.

description: InStuntman, you'll perform dangerous stunts in three or four vehicles as you play the part of a Hollywood stuntman for hire. You'll need to be good: the stunts will get harder, and you must accumulate skills to progress from low-budget productions to multimillion-dollar Hollywood blockbusters. Each stunt consists of a series of clearly defined objectives, which can range from 180-degree spins to perfectly timed jumps, dramatic barrel rolls, and T-bone smashes. To succeed, the player must achieve all or some of each scene's set objectives. Stunts take place on movie sets in six different countries around the world; completing each stunt rewards you with bonus items for use in the Stunt Arena, which you create yourself.Stuntmanwas developed with the help of one of the movies' most experienced stuntmen, Vic Armstrong.
reviewText: In this game, you are a driver of many different vehicles from Monster Trucks, Cars, Jeeps, Motorcycles, Snowmobiles, and Vans.  You go through many segments that make up a movie which you watch once your done with the segments.  The game can get very difficult in some scenes.  I have tried some scenes at least 50 times before I completed it, that is how hard it is.  There isn't a difficulty setting either.  Practice makes perfect when your playing this game.  They should have made it easier so you wouldn't be stuck on one level for 3 days, but I guess that is why the game is so short.  It has a very fun stunt constructor mode, where you set up ramps, cars, and fire rings for your car to demolish.  It is very fun.  The whole game in itself can get pretty addicting, but once you figure you can't complete a level after trying it 40 times, you pretty much just give up because it is so annoying.  I am not sure if I wanted to get the second one or not because of this, but overall, it is a cool game and deserves at least 4 stars.

Unlike some and seems most reviews this review is from a playing point of view of an adult. I've wanted this game since i saw it released over seas (called Forever Blue over there). I love the ocean and sea creatures, except sharks but the great part about this game is you can't die. I like this game for it's pure enjoyment, no other reason than that. Though it would be a great learning tool.Plot:Though you can not lose, die, or make mistakes in this game there is a goal. The goal of the game is to find a certain creature in the ocean, which you're boat mate tells you about as you progress in the game. The plot also thickens as you venture further and further out into the ocean. I don't want to give it away but it does have to do with your boat mate and she kind of gives you the story as to why she is out in the ocean and her background and asks for your help to find the creature.Controls:They are easy as pie. Press B and point and it gets you everywhere you want to go. You can take pictures with your camera, save them in an album, draw underwater with your underwater pen, feed the animals, pet the animals, train dolphins, and swim hands free all with ease.Pros:-Learn about sea life and creatures-It's like a hunt for treasure sometimes-How interactive it is-You can have online play with other friends who own the game-There is no loseing, dieing or time limit-You can stop at any point and save-You can put in your own SD card and listen to your own music while you swim-Being a diving instructor-Being the camera "guy" for a magazine-You get to fill the aquarium with fish of your choice-The video is awesome when you find some new underwater holeCons:There is only one thing that i would have liked to see more of and that is special requests. Diving requests, you take people around the ocean and try and find a certain fish/creature they wanted to see. Or picture reuquests, you get small and big fish requests for a magazine.Overall i think it's a great game. Sometimes i can sit there for so long i lose track of time. I think it's great for any age range, though it isn't packed full of action it does have it's perks.Other games i enjoy if you want to see if you relate to my likes and dislikes:-The Sims-Mario Kart-CSI-Metroid-Resident Evil-Guitar Hero-And of course Endless Ocean

description: Enables DVD movie playback functionality on the Xbox video game system. Includes a DVD remote control and an infrared receiver that plugs into an Xbox controller port.Note: this item is required for DVD movie playback on Xbox.
summary: Doubles your xbox as a DVD Player, but lots of cons
reviewText: PROS- works fine. No IR connection problems.- great for people that don't already have a DVD player.CONS- doesn't play DVDs in progressive scan. Why not? They can make games in 480p (old HD) for the xbox.- takes up a controller port slot. Not a big deal, but if you often have 4 friends playing, you won't be able to leave it in all the time.- no backlit or glow- no eject button- no power button. What? Never seen a remote without a power button. Thus you CANNOT turn your xbox on/off with this remote.- cannot learn- not universal. If you have lots of remotes, you're better off learning this one into a universal remote.- many people already own a DVD player, many with progressive scan.

People have been bashing this game. Just becuase someone gave it a bad review doesn't mean you have to go into the game looking for promblems. You'll set yourself up for disappointment. I chose to completely ignore the reviews and judge the game by my own standards. Let me start by saying that I own all the Suikodens and the IV plays like a Suikoden should. The game has its flaws {the main character looks and moves stupid} but it isn't to the degree that people make it out to be. Someone said the graphics suck. I take it that person didn't really pay attention to the first three. If he had, he'd of realized that these graphics {though not stunning} are better than any Suikoden's ever had. Not saying this is the best Suikoden, but if you truely consider yourself a fan, then you shouldn't be dissapointed. I've seen reviews as low as 1 star.  ..... C'mon people, just cause it didn't knock your socks off doesn't mean you have to hate like that. Don't call the game BAD because it didn't meet YOUR expectations. I'm not far enough to say where this game fits in compared to the other three. But I am far enough to defend it against 1 star rating HATERS. If you call yourself a fan, you can get the game {which is $39 instead of $49} and judge it for yourself. You owe Konami that.

description: The third instalment in Nintendo’s popular Super Smash Bros. fighter franchise debuts on the Wii in Super Smash Bros. Brawl. Loaded with all the characters and features players have loved from the two previous versions, plus much more, it is a worthy addition to the series and yet another must-have title for the Nintendo Wii. Engage the rage with Super Smash Bros. Brawl! The third instalment of the incredibly successful Super Smash Bros. series is now on the Wii, The roster islonger than ever, but that just means more butt to kick across over a dozen different, graphic-rich stages with original moves, new modified moves, and a brand-new super attack called Final Smash! Old favourites like Mario, Link, Peach and Kirby are now joined by such exciting newcomers as Wario, Solid Snake and Sonic the Hedgehog. With a variety of new modes, an absolutely epic soundtrack and the ability to play with distant friends through online multiplayer, this is a game you'll have to break your own fingers to put down. Original soundtrack from 36 different artists Online Multiplayer. See your favourite Smash Bros. character, redesigned from their most recent games, brawl onto your screen once again! A host of new characters to fight with, including Sonic, Pit from Kid Icarus, Wario and Diddy Kong. More than a dozen gorgeously-rendered stages. New special moves and attacks, including the groundbreaking Final Smash. New items and assist trophies.
reviewText: When I was a youngster, Super Smash Bros. for N64 came out. I still recall the commercial where Mario, Yoshi, and Donkey Kong are dancing through a field, and then proceed to fight each other. The game's premise (Nintendo characters fighting each other) sounded like a great idea for a game, and it was. The original Super Smash Bros. was fun, but it had one small problem: not enough content. I don't recall how long it took me to unlock everything in that game, but it didn't take very long. After doing all of the 1-player stuff, SSB was only good for the occasional battle with friends who'd rather fight on an N64 wrestling game! :P I remember thinking to myself, "This game is great, but they should make another one with about twenty times as much content!"Fast forward gods know how many years: The game I dreamed of as a child has been made. I haven't finished unlocking all of the content in this game, and I don't know if I will. Completing all of the challenges would take true dedication and a good bit of Super Smash Bros. skills.The final unlockable in the original game was the Sound Test menu. In Brawl, they give you that menu from the word go, but you're constantly unlocking and/or trying to unlock new songs. The massive soundtrack in this game rocks. It's a hard rock affair. As one might expect, it's chock full of memorable melodies related to game's many Nintendo characters.Speaking of characters, there are plenty to go around. Along with the obligatory "charter" characters like Link, Samus, and Mario, you've got obscure and interesting characters like R.O.B. the Robot and Ice Climbers. Also, there are some non-Nintendo characters in this game like Sonic the Hedgehog and Solid Snake.The stages are interesting. There's a Donkey Kong Country style level, a pirate ship, a falling glacier, a Mario Kart track, the Bridge of Eldin from Twilight Princess, and many other fun places. Brawl also has some of the stages from Super Smash Bros.: Melee. I rather like the Donkey Kong themed level out of those. They're all pretty great though.This game also has a Stage Builder for making your own Super Smash Bros. levels. Its potential is limited by the scant variety of building blocks they give you, but with a little creativity, you can actually make convincing versions of stages from a lot of video games. It's really good for making Atari and NES games, as those games tended to use simple square shapes like those within the SSBB Stage Builder. Seriously, this feature alone is hours upon hours of fun.As far as I'm concerned, the only real problem with Super Smash Bros. is its online mode. Lag is far too frequent for a game that only allows four players to play in a given match. Also, this is one of those Wii titles that use friend codes. So, if you don't know anyone else with this game, or if you don't feel like joining a Super Smash Bros. Brawl related forum, you'll have to play anonymously against other people. But having said all of that, it's good to own a Super Smash Bros. game that you can play online.So, Super Smash Bros. brawl is an excellent offline game, but the online mode might as well not even be there. The end result is something that feels like one really awesome Nintendo 64 game. That is exactly what I wanted. Bravo, Nintendo! Bravo!

description: Final Fantasy Xis the first title in this landmark RPG series to be released for the PlayStation2. The main characters are Tidus, a star of blitzball (a hugely popular sport in the Final Fantasy universe), and Yuna, who has learned the art of summoning and controlling aeons, powerful spirits of yore. These two people of different backgrounds must work together as they journey through the world of Spira. This installment of Final Fantasy has a distinctly Asian influence, bringing a fresh feel to the characters, music, settings, and story.Features include voice-overs for the first time in the series (utilizing the Facial Motion System), high-polygon, motion-captured player characters designed by Tetsuya Nomura, and a camera that automatically adjusts its perspective to correspond with the movements of the characters--a feature now possible because the game is largely polygonal.
summary: The new Final Fantasy cinematic phenomenon
reviewText: Here is the epitome of the future of next-gen Japanese RPGs, in full theatrical splendor, for better or for worse.Final Fantasy X is a visually beautiful masterpiece with a deep, dramatic story and a unique twist in RPG gameplay.FFX is definitely be one of the most gorgeous Final Fantasy games of all time. The backgrounds are amazingly realistic and exotic. The enemies are collosal. And with the new addition of voice actors, FFX is easily one of the most dramatic Final Fantasy games.Also, the new experience system is one of the most entertaining parts of the game. Players can assign their own abilities to the characters by following a grid system. Parts of the grid are conveniently sectioned off with locks, so that they can't get the super-powerful Ultima spell until nearly the end of the game. However, the best part of FFX is the new opportunity for players to customize their characters.Some parts of FFX are a little frustrating, to say the least. The battle system is a rather bland turn-based strategy system, in which players can trade off certain characters to defeat certain characters. This system tends to keep some of the weaker characters, such as the summoner Yuna, from earning the experience they need for more crucial abilities.Also, there isn't a humongous world map in FFX. Since this game is realistic down to the bone, we get to experience every part of the entire party's road trip, moving across calm plains and thunderstorm-drenching valleys. And they even spend large amounts of time socializing on boats and ferries. It's almost too exhausting to sit through so many cutscenes of spoken dialogue, with the occasional awkward translation problem.However, this is the beauty of Final Fantasy X--it offers players the fully engaging experience of traveling everywhere and anywhere with their characters, killing the most fearsome beasts, and rejecting the awful fate that lies ahead of them.And the story is one of the very best in Final Fantasy history. The main characters is Tidus, the Zanarkand blitzball player who warped 1,000 years ahead in time to a world where Zanarkand is now devastated. He is faced with the daunting task of facing the father who deserted him a long time ago and helping his friend, Yuna, defeat Sin. More importantly, people are left wondering how Tidus managed to survive the devastating encounter with Sin 1,000 years ago.In spite of its flaws, "Final Fantasy X" is a visual masterpiece for the new millenium, a game that encompasses the defiance of a pre-determined fate of annihilation.

reviewText: This game is pretty tricky, but becomes pretty easy once you get the hang of things. First, a disclaimer:  For those that have played Madden since the PS2 generation, I think the best two are...PS2:  Madden 2005 (and indeed, I think this is the best one period)PS3:  Madden 2010 (play 2012 and go back to 2010, the presentation is so much better)Which brings me to Madden NFL 2012.  I hestiated to buy this until my wife made the suggestions, who am I to argue?  I had heard things about the "Dynamic Player Performance" and all the other improvements, so I said what the heck?First, the good:- The game is looking great graphically.  They've nailed the stadiums (and indeed, a lot of the intros), the menus are sharp and easy to read, and overall it's more polished then other PS3 Maddens.- GameFlow returns but for someone like me who has played with the Steelers for many years, and knows their best plays, it's nice the conventional option was left.  I was up and running in no time even though it had been many months since I played Madden.- The online community/matchmaking process has been significantly improved and the trolls/cheaters that have plagued this game online for years is likely to be all but eliminated, so kudos for EA for finally getting this fixed.Now, the not-so-good:- I read a lot of reviews before purchasing this game, and let me tell you that they nailed one thing:  The announcing is HORRIBLE in this game.  A few examples:*I'm up 35-0 and they go "The Ravens better do something on this drive because if they don't, man it's going to be a long day".  You think?*TWO times I know i heard Gus Johnson refer to my offense as the DEFENSE...how in the WORLD does that get in a final product?You would think in 2011 they could get this right...but no.  It still sucks.- While the graphics are good, the actual game performance leaves somethings to be desired.  Clipping is rampant (not the football penalty), a couple times in my first game the crowd (cardboard and pixelated as it was) got in front of the players on a cutscene, they play the SAME cutscenes after a guy scores a TD, I mean I could go on and on but this stuff should be fixed by the 2012 game now.- The difficulty has some seriously wild swings that are either way too easy or ludiciously difficult.  Is it too much to ask to have a nice middle ground?- This might be the easiest set of sport game trophies to earn on the PS3.  I got SIX of them in my very first game!  And the only ones I see that are majorly difficult are the ones that require 100 yard returns for TD's.  Past games have had a lot more specific challenges and they had to be played in All Pro...these can be earned on any difficulty level.- It was tremendously easy in Madden 2005 to manage your Franchise (players, etc.) but this interface is way too clunky for its own good, even with all the details they added.  Sometimes simple presentation is MUCH better.- Why Madden went away from what they had in 2010 (i.e. the halftime show, etc.) is beyond me.  The lame excuse they have in its place (a couple random highlights) is a joke.  Oh, and I guess Gus Johnson couldn't be bothered to say the teams NAMES when he says what the score is at the end of every quarter!  I have NEVER seen that in all the years I've played Madden.And in the end, EA doesn't care.  They know there will be a significant part of the population that will pick it up just because it's the next game in the series.  Games like NHL 11 (and upcoming 12) have advanced and are now far superior to the NFL product, but of course Madden's going to sell like hotcakes so they don't care.So, if you're someone that likes the updated rosters, and can appreciate the few improvements they put in, go ahead and buy it again.  Just know what you'er getting.  I don't see this game drawing any new players into Madden who haven't played it before, and Madden's got a long road to climb back that we probably won't see until the PS4/next Xbox generation.
